name: Perceived Usefulness
definition: The degree to which a person believes that using a particular system would enhance his or her job performance.
sourcePaper: Davis (1989) - Perceived Usefulness, Perceived Ease of Use, and User Acceptance of Information Technology
measurementItems: Using the system improves my performance in my job.
Using the system increases my productivity.
Using the system enhances my effectiveness.
I find the system useful in my job.
notes: Core construct in technology acceptance. Often mediates the effect of PEOU on intention.

name: Perceived Ease of Use
definition: The degree to which a person believes that using a particular system would be free of effort.
sourcePaper: Davis (1989) - Perceived Usefulness, Perceived Ease of Use, and User Acceptance of Information Technology
measurementItems: Learning to operate the system is easy for me.
I find it easy to get the system to do what I want.
My interaction with the system is clear and understandable.
I find the system flexible to interact with.
notes: Often has both direct and indirect (via PU) effects on behavioral intention.

name: Behavioral Intention
definition: A person's subjective probability that he or she will perform a specified behavior.
sourcePaper: Fishbein & Ajzen (1975) - Belief, Attitude, Intention, and Behavior
theoreticalDomain: Theory of Reasoned Action / Planned Behavior
measurementItems: I intend to use the system in the future.
I will try to use the system in my daily work.
I plan to continue using the system.
notes: Key predictor of actual behavior in TRA/TPB. Mediates attitudes toward behavior.

name: Confirmation
definition: The extent to which the user's experience with the information system confirms his or her pre-acceptance expectations.
measurementItems: My experience with using the system was better than I expected.
The service level provided by the system was better than I expected.
Overall, most of my expectations from using the system were confirmed.
notes: Central to post-adoption research. Disconfirmation (negative confirmation) drives satisfaction changes.

name: Satisfaction
definition: The affective state reflecting the degree to which the user is pleased with the prior use of the information system.
sourcePaper: Oliver (1980) - A Cognitive Model of the Antecedents and Consequences of Satisfaction
measurementItems: I am satisfied with the performance of the system.
I am pleased with the experience of using the system.
I am contented with the use of the system.
notes: Key mediator between confirmation and continuance intention in ECM.

name: Continuance Intention
definition: The intention of a user to continue using an information system following initial adoption.
measurementItems: I intend to continue using the system rather than discontinue.
My intentions are to continue using the system.
I will keep using the system as regularly as I do now.
notes: Post-adoption equivalent of behavioral intention. Different from adoption intention.

name: Expectations
definition: Pre-consumption beliefs about product or service performance.
sourcePaper: Oliver (1980) - A Cognitive Model of the Antecedents and Consequences of Satisfaction
measurementItems: Pre-exposure expectation items adapted to context

name: Perceived Performance
definition: The user's perception of how the system actually performed.
measurementItems: Performance perception items adapted to IS context
notes: Compared against expectations to form confirmation.

name: Actual Usage
definition: The actual behavior of using the information system.
measurementItems: Self-reported or system-captured usage metrics
notes: Outcome of behavioral intention in adoption models.
